The room had all the luxuries you would expect, ( 3 Plasma TV's and DVD's, large soaking tub with views of the sea, exquisite linens and down duvet and oversized pilows, rainforest shower), but we appreciated the Bose iPod docking station the most. The staff were very willing to share thier local knowledge, of where to go and what and when to see, and this also helped us miss the crowds and find those rare and special places. We really liked the size of the hotel, only 65 rooms as it made the experience, much more personal and intimate, as you would normally only get from a small boutique property. Full business services in the hotel, as well as a Spa and fitness centre. We highly recommend this property, and are sure you will not be disappointed.

Reviews.Title: “The Standard by Which All Other Hotels Should be Judged”
Reviews.Author: dicooley
Reviews.Content: If you can afford it (and that's a big if at these prices), this is THE place to stay in Istanbul. I stayed here first in 2003 and again last month (2008). I almost didn't stay here again because of the price; that would have been a huge mistake. This fabulous hotel is flawless and worth the price of admission. For first time visitors to Istanbul it is the absolute best location possible and that's just the beginning. The concierge, the front desk staff, the door staff, housekeeping--everyone there is looking out for you and taking care of you at all times. It's a small hotel so they know you by name and address you as such. We were traveling with family members who stayed at other hotels, when they came to the Four Seasons to meet up with us the hotel staff not only knew when we were there and when we weren't, but also recognized our traveling companions immediately and would tell them as soon as they came through the front door ("Oh, I'm sorry you just missed them"). Now that's service. The rooms are wonderfully appointed (flat screen tvs, l'occitane products) and exceptionally quiet. My room had a balcony with an amazing view of Hagia Sophia. There is a nice, well-equipped gym (including sauna), which is somewhat rare in European hotels; it's a little small but has everything you need for a good workout. The only downside to this hotel is the price, not only is it expensive per night but once you're there nothing is free or cheap: internet access 22 euro per day, simple breakfast for two 55 euro; dinner 100 euro pp, etc. Nevertheless, it's worth every penny.

Reviews.Title: “Update to previous review...GREAT CONCIERGE”
Reviews.Author: JMBINCA
Reviews.Content: I wrote a prior review of the Four Seasons Sultanahmet, and stand by all the good things I wrote about the hotel. I wanted to write this update because the positive Four Seasons experience continues now that we are home. We bought some ceramic items from a gift shop near the hotel. They were to ship the items to the U.S. for us, so we didn't have to carry them on the plane. The proprietor of the gift shop seemed very trustworthy, so we didn't have concerns about doing this. However, we have been back a month and still don't have the items. Plus, the proprietor wouldn't return our calls or emails. So, I emailed the Concierge at the Four Seasons and asked him to drop by the shop and inquire about our items. Twelve hours after I sent the email, I had the proprietor on the phone apologizing effusively. He claimed that there was an error at FedEx, but I think the real issue was he didn't want to disappoint the Four Seasons given a lot of his customers stay there. Just a great example of how the Four Seasons truly cares about their guests and will go the extra mile to help them out...even after their stay has ended. Suffice it to say, you can stay at this hotel with confidence.

Reviews.Title: “Awesome hotel. Outstanding Service. Best Location in Istanbul”
Reviews.Author: SkiandSkate
Reviews.Content: We returned recently from a wonderful three day stay at the Four Seasons Istanbul at Sultanahmet. We had five star treatments from the moment we arrived. The property is beautiful and the BEST location in the city for sightseeing. We had a room on the fourth floor since we requested a balcony with a inner courtyard view as well as the Blue Mosque and the Bosporus. The room was plenty big and very luxurious - a la Four Seasons. Huge bathrooms. If you want a private balcony with a great view - it's perfect. Otherwise the third floor would be great, any lower your view is limited. You definietly want a courtyard room - outside rooms are the least desirable. One advantage to the fourth floor is that there are two additional balconies on both ends of the floor. It made it very convenient to sit outside and relax. One balcony had the lounge chairs set up like a pool area. That side was ideal for a little privacy and a spectacular view. The other side had the balcony bar. We have traveled extensively and this city hotel is one of the best and worth the money. The concierge recommended a great outdoor fish restaurant in walking distance, a nice inexpensive breakfast place, and we dined in the hotel restaurant for our last nightâ€™s dinner. The ambience of dining in the courtyard, excellent food and service, made a wonderful evening. It was priced reasonable for the hotel. You were known and greeted by name from the moment you arrived and until you checked out. We needed cabs to go to the airport very early in the morning. The hotel arranged for them to arrive on time, paid them and added it to our hotel bill (as we were out of Turkish Lira). Five Stars all the way.

Reviews.Title: “Great location - not as good as expected”
Reviews.Author: Neil-from-Dallas
Reviews.Content: Finally got around to writing this review - we stayed 4 days in June. First time we visited Istanbul so we arranged in advance through the four seasons to be picked up from the airport. We could not find the driver when we got through the customs area. It was a mess and we almost ended up with some rip-off car service so I would strongly recomend that the hotel has some better way of locating their guest when they arive. After we finally found our car and driver, things went a bit better! We were tired from the long flight and the airport issues and the first room that we were shown just didn't get it! It was dark and at the back of the property, the windows looked out over a "dig" - I called it a constructions site! And there was some kind of noise making machinerey that drove me nuts all night! I insisted that they find us a better room the next day or we would check out! FINALLY we "made a deal" and ended up with the Presidential Suite! It ended up costing us about double our regular room rate but it made up for some of the issues, I guess?! The location of the property is great - all of the other reviews have already covered that. You can walk to most of the sites that you will want to see. One caveat though is when ever and where ever you walk people pester you trying to sell you rugs and other crap! Like a mexican beach on steriods! The restauant is nothing special. Common areas are well kept, the courtyard is beautiful.

Reviews.Title: “Perfect oasis in bustling Istanbul”
Reviews.Author: ryzee
Reviews.Content: Stayed at the Four Seasons Sultanahmet for 5 nights before transferring to the brand new Four Seasons Istanbul on the Bosphorus for 3 nights and that is the way to do it. The Sultanahmet location is on a quiet side street yet only a short walk to all the sites one would want to see in the old town. The hotel is small and intimate and the staff really get to know you. We were in a deluxe room which while not huge was a nice size and very comfortable. Housekeeping was amazing. I never once saw a housekeeper doing any of the twice daily housekeeping, the room was magically attended to whenever we where out. All of this does not come without a price, food and beverage is expensive but you just need to remind yourself that you are not buying the beer (for $15) you are buying the Four Seasons brand, the gorgeous terrace, the perfect staff. The Bosphorus location from where I write this is a totally different hotel and perfect in a totally different way. Review of Bosphorus to follow.

Reviews.Title: “Service, Service, Service!!!!”
Reviews.Author: rogfamNy
Reviews.Content: It really doesn't get much better than the Four Seasons. Besides the excellent location near all the sights in the Old City, the service was outstanding, even by Four Seasons standards. When we arrived early from our flight, our room wasn't ready. The front desk took my cell phone number and told us to go and enjoy the sights. We did, and a short time later I received a call that our room was ready! Also, while we were out, friends who we were meeting, called the hotel to say that they were delayed....the hotel forwarded the call to my cell phone. I had informed the hotel on our reservation that it was our anniversary. We ate in the excellent Seasons restaurant, and for dessert that surprised us with champagne and a cake. Returning to our room later that evening a second anniversary cake was waiting.

Reviews.Title: “Fabulous Hotel”
Reviews.Author: Harry1203
Reviews.Content: The Four Seasons Istanbul at Sultanahmet is an exquisite hotel that is elegant, clean, with impecable service. The concierge is one of the best I've ever seen and the staff are friendly and helpful. The rooms are luxurious with great views of the Blue mosque and Haya Sofia. The breakfast was to die for and the Seasons restaurant is one of the best in the city. Only thing missing was a pool! Without a doubt, I would stay their again

Reviews.Title: “The best hotel in europe”
Reviews.Author: xcapeohio
Reviews.Content: I don't see how you can't give this hotel a 5 star rating. I can't say enough great things about them from the staff, the room, the location. This is many times better than any other 5 star hotel I have stayed at. It was my wife's birthday and we could only splurge for one night, they made it unbelievable. They left a cake for her and were always bringing little gifts. The room was the most impressive room I have ever stayed in. The bed and bath, perfect. I am very picky and I always find little things that bother me, there was nothing here, they have achieved perfection.

Reviews.Title: “Not flawless”
Reviews.Author: Doctorheart
Reviews.Content: We stayed 8 nights.. 12 April to 19 1. Excellent location, cozy , but can be detailed inside better..! 2. Excellent breakfast place. 3. Friendly staff..(outstanding concierge, excellent receptionists, and one of kind room manager (forgot the name , ? Ehrkan.., very nice , He placed us in a nearby nice room, Do not try to call for the manager because he did not answer our calls, for one nite extension, gave us a counter descending look in a nearby cafe..!! on our 6 th nite stay, the cafÃ© owner told us of his name and presence after he noticed our map, Mr.Fâ€¦d, from Egypt) ..Do not believe hotel is fully booked , cause there is always rooms spared for emergencies Be surprised if some showed an attitudes, because Turkish hotel workers are one of the best in the world., in fact some did during our stay..! 4. Cleanness is a credit to a very professional and very polite housekeepers.. 5. Nice room but no exceptional..(do not count on upgrade. I did not get one!, I told them I pay for a suite, but was not able to get it) 6. Room service call receiver is an average or below average 5 stars hotel, missed our orders in two occasions and delays is the rule..! 7. Depressing Gym , small , poor light,. no Windows.., basement of a former jail house, suggest to close it!. So Is it good place? You bit it is.. Is it perfect? , is it the best hotel in Europe? (as advertised) is it worth 560 Euro/nite? (what I paid) The answer is a simple and sure no.. Will we go back again, a timid Yes, and hope to find a management change, newer Gym, better room service, better daily room fruit and perhaps, morning windows de-curtaining to enter the competitive world of luxury lodging.

Reviews.Title: “Mixed beauty”
Reviews.Author: WildGoomba
Reviews.Content: This hotel was how we spent the last 2 days of our honeymoon in Turkey. While I am writing this review a little too late considering it's been almost 2 years I went thought I would put my words down, Firstly, Make no mistake this is a brilliant hotel in an even better location so good that I ended up walking upto the blue mosque and the hagia sophia 2-3 times a day whenever we were at the hotel. And ofcourse it is surrounded by the magical part of Istanbul. The hotel also upgraded us from the Four Seasons room to a higher class which we greatly appreciated but once we got into the rooms it was not something one hasnt seen in much cheaper hotels, While I agree the hotel must have certain limitations in terms of Architecture being an old building it still does not have the passion that one finds in few other boutique hotles (Devi Garh India) comes to mind. Everything about the place feels a little very professional which is not a bad thing but I believe a hotel of this kind could do with a little more ... But maybe the target audience prefer this way of life? I also had a problem with the dining as there was only one restaurant and my Wife being a Vegetarian had little to choose from and ended up eating only salads thanks to a great manager at the restaurant. Like I said, This hotel is brilliant, The location is Excellent, The staff is one of the best you can find... but it just remains a hotel not a memory one takes back home!

Reviews.Title: “mostly great”
Reviews.Author: Olive66
Reviews.Content: Beautiful hotel in the heart of old Istanbul. The old prison, and yes there's no question we'd love to be imprisoned there. So close to the Blue Mosque and Agia Sophia etc. Best tip - wander out at night when the crowds have gone to view the buildings from outside in the twilight/dark - the majesty blew me away much more than during the bustling daytime. The roads are cobbled so wear high heels with caution, but it's still possible. We stayed in a 4 seasons room (120) which was a lovely haven - faces the outside garden, not the courtyard. The construction of the extension woke us up every morning, not ideal but didn't start til approx 9am so actually it gets you up in time for brakfast which is a very adequate buffet most days. Bathroom very good, Occitane products. Fresh fruit and water daily. Red wine in the minibar was badly corked, they replaced it, didn't charge us for it and sent us a cheese plate. Housekeeping and room service excellent, as expected at these prices. I happened to be in the room, a staff member came in to change the ice, asked me how I was - said slight cough so he brought me apple tea and an extra box of tissues. Restaurant was standard western client stuff - for me a bit dull tasting, no adventure and fairly highly priced, however reliable and it is peaceful which is something that one comes to appreciate in this bustling place. Bar is fine, good staff. Only complaint really would be the concierge desk. Sent 2 emails regarding arranging an airport transfer - no reply (even though the booking confirmation asked if we wanted transfer info sending) but in fact all you need to do is jump in a taxi at the airport, cost approx 30 lira. Even worse they recommended a restaurant specifically with a Bosphorus View, took one hour to drive there in a taxi (traffic is heavy but part of the scene) and when we arrived there was no reservation. We were given a terrible table where the waiters bumped into my husband, and we couldn't even see the Bosphorus! The food was minimal but worse, supposedly fresh sea bass which wasn't at all fresh. Always suspicious when you place an order and it arrives within minutes, as it's obviously been cooked and lined up for unsuspecting tourists. Â£100 bill for poor food and experience - avoid the Park Fora - you have been warned. Unfortunately we did tell the concierge but they didn't take it seriously, and I suspect they'll recommend this restaurant to you. The Sabbatin fish restaurant 5 minutes walk from the hotel (in the guides) serves much better fresh fish, it's slightly frenetic ,but honest and the red mullet was memorable. Best restaurants seen to be outside Sultanamet. Develi do good kebabs (and I'm usually not a big fan) and they also have non-smoking which is a touch unusual here! My second tip is if you're a wine drinker, drink local wine, better wines are absolutely fine and compliment the food, as foreign wine has hefty taxes attached. Gym in the hotel was actually very enjoyable for us so we went daily - good equipment - 3 lifefitness treadmills and a cross trainer, plus bike machines, weights etc with TV screens. Small but not many people go there. Friendly gym staff. Shame no pool but I think hamams are the thing in Istanbul not swimming. Saunas in the changing rooms. Overall a special hotel, as you would anticipate. Concierge advice slightly lacking.

Reviews.Title: “The Perfect Hotel in the Perfect Location”
Reviews.Author: rcullet
Reviews.Content: I've come to expect Four Season's Hotels to be flawless and this one is no exception. The concierge found us a helicopter with 30 minutes notice. The bartender always remembered what we drank and even opened the bar at 3am for us. :) There are only 63 rooms/suites in this hotel and it seemed there was a staff member for every room. We stayed in 326. This room has view of the Sea. We sent laundry in at noon and it was back at 7pm. They even returned the money they found in my pockets. Every request we made was met with a smile. What wasn't expected was the location. You can walk to all the major attractions in Sultanahmet from here, including Haghia Sofia, The Blue Mosque, The Basilic Cistern and even the Grand Bazaar. You could not find a more convenient location. Yet it is tucked away just enough to be off the well beaten tourist path. If you are going to Istanbul this is the place to stay. The hotel has wireless and wired high speed internet. AT&T roams for both data and voice. Reception was very good.

Reviews.Title: “Great hotel, lovely location, fabtastic staff”
Reviews.Author: simonww
Reviews.Content: You cannot fault the hotel, it is fabulous, especially the staff who did everything they could to help us enjoy our visit. Our room was lovely with a great view, the food in the restaurant beautifully prepared and served. Like any big city, the sharks are there waiting outside, but the real locals are welcoming and friendly. We hired our own boat for a trip around the harbour, much better than the tourist boats. Eat in the fish market, very cheap and enjoyable. Where possible take a ferry around the harbour, it is very cheap and great fun.

Reviews.Title: “Great Hotel”
Reviews.Author: Mctaffish
Reviews.Content: Stayed at this hotel for a special anniversay & the hotel could not do enough for us. They upgraded our room, we had a happy anniversay cake waiting for us in our room on arrival & even a special anniversay desert after our dinner there on the first evening. The hotel is in an excellent location for the old town, absolutely everything is within walking distance. All the staff were very helpful, including things like recommending restaurants & advising on directions everytime we left the hotel. It is very pricey to eat & drink there but this is to be expected at a hotel of this status. Istanbul is a facinating place that I have always wanted to visit & staying at the Four Seasons was the icing on the cake.

Reviews.Title: “Not quite as good as I hoped for....”
Reviews.Author: aebp25
Reviews.Content: We spent 4 nights at the Four Seasons and had time to get to know the hotel. On the whole, it is lovely. Is it truly worth the price...I don't think so. But if you have the money, it isn't a horrible way to spend it. Pros: --The absolute best part of the hotel is the location if your primary goal is to see the historical sights. It really doesn't get any better than this. We enjoyed being able to get to everything so quickly. --Great concierge service that was very helpful and polite. You won't get the most inventive or interesting food recommendations, but they will be very solid. Great at making and rearranging reservations. --The staff is always incredibly gracious --Rooms are very spacious and the house keeping does a good job. Cons --The construction of the addition isn't the most pleasant thing to be next to all day. --The site is very historical, but the decor on the whole seems generic --The nickel and diming is a bit ridiculous. $20 bucks for coffee each morning? More to use the internet connection? (Tip: If you are a VERY early riser they have coffee, tea and some bread in the lobby but it is removed around 6:30 AM) Of course, if you are staying there, money isn't the biggest issue, it is just surprising. --The gym area is serviceable, but very small. --As in all of Istanbul, smoking is everywhere. The lobby and the bar are filled with smoke constantly. There is a non-smoking isolation room in the back of the bar. --The restaurant is very luxurious, but by no means worth the price. The only thing I really remember is the spiced ice cream at the end of the meal. If someone else was paying, I would of course stay there. But I won't be footing the bill again.

Reviews.Title: “Worth every penny”
Reviews.Author: Dean07
Reviews.Content: If you're like us, you're researching here to decide if it's really worth splurging on this hotel. Consider that there are many things to spend your money on in Istanbul, yet in my view, few will provide the same value as a night's stay at the Four Seasons, Sultanahmet. True, this is an expensive hotel, but you get a lot for your money. All the previous posts about the hotelâ€™s luxuries and services are 100% true, so no need to repeat here. There's something about the Turkish culture that lends itself to producing incredibly friendly, helpful staff. The Four Seasons around the world have the same training and management philosophies, but I have a hunch the secret ingredient here is the Turkish people (the staff) that puts this location at the top of ratings lists. I thought the second most impressive aspect of the hotel is its tasteful integration within the old city part of town. It just fits comfortably within its surroundings. Not ostentatious. So, in contrast to the farcically over-priced tourist-related places, restaurants, taxis, shops etc (as compared to other big cities and relative quality expectations), we did feel the Four Season provided a good value. (Other than this hotel, I felt my 20 dollar haircut and shave provided that next best value!) The public transportation system is a great option to taxis, as the tram system is very user friendly, as are the ferries to the Asian side and the underground funicular to Taksim. People are very helpful if you have questions. I suppose there are good buys on carpets and other high end goods, but my advice would be stay away unless you really know your stuff â€“ they'll eat you alive thereâ€¦especially the typically timid American. Definitely haggle on your souvenir shopping and you can do OK. Do take note of just how many carpets and other high end goods are for sale everywhere and consider the "sales effort" that goes into the process. Like me, you may find it odd to observe so few high-end goods really being purchased yet so much being offered. Save the money for your stay at the Fourâ€™s Seasons, enjoy the kindness of your Turkish hosts, and stroll the sights of this beautiful, historic city.

Reviews.Title: “Stay here at least once in your life”
Reviews.Author: SAF18
Reviews.Content: Upon our arrival to the four seasons we immediately fell at home, we were given a room on the second floor overlooking the street. The room was huge, and the bathroom incredible. Amenities were superbe with courtesy mineral water and fresh fruit every day refreshed. Hotel staff was over 5 stars, this is what I call luxury service, the most often pronounced words were â€œcertainlyâ€� and each guests names. In fact, they made us feel as if they knew us from a long time. Just an example of what you can expect in this hotel as serviceâ€¦ one night, the room service housekeeper , while he was servicing our room at night, saw me bare foot (I had just taken my shoes off) and he immediately came over and slipped on a pair of warm slippers for me to heat up my feet. It is these kind of details that truly make a distinction in one hotel. If I could describe the feeling upon entering this hotel is that of happiness and well being, as soon as you enter the doorway and you see the incredible flower setup in the lobby you are set for a big smile. Not everything was so perfect, we indeed had a problem with our room on the third day of our stay, there was a leak from the room upstairs. Yet the service once again was unbeatable! We were immediately upgraded to an executive four seasons room which was even bigger than our first room and overlooking the garden. Thousands apologies and the most rapid service that I have ever seen in my life. Concierges were incredible, always ready to help in any way, and recommending outstanding restaurants (not necessarily touristy or luxurious) Sunday brunch was just amazing â€“ delicious! Car service to the airport was pure luxury. A silver bmw sedan drove us to the airport, this included the kindest driver, some Turkish delights for us to eat and some refreshments. I wanted to stop by a shopping center to do some shopping and the driver graciously waited for us while we shopped. All in all, I cannot recommend this hotel highly enough! It is an absolutely priviledge being able to spend just a day at this four seasons! so in conclusion, do stay here at least once in your life!

Reviews.Title: “love it the best locationin istanbul”
Reviews.Author: nicwest
Reviews.Content: One of the best hotel we ever stayed!! Service ,room ,location!! If you could afford it and there is some good deal on the hotel site this is the best hotel to enjoy Istanbul The hotel by itself is spectacular, the courtyard as well as the roof top with view of the city.From the hotel you could walk to most of the sites. The street around are very nice and safe and the concierge recomended some very good and inexpensive restaurant around. But one night we had the turkish buffet at the hotel ,very good. One wrong think: the concierge told us to take the local ferry to the Bosphorus it is a zoo!! not a pleasant experience better to take a nice tour in a tourist boat.Also avoid the grand bazzar a tourist trap not better than Canal street in New york!!l

Reviews.Title: “Fab hotel and location”
Reviews.Author: winnie88
Reviews.Content: We had a wonderful experience at this hotel. The service was excellent and the room and bathroom were very well appointed. We had arrived very early in the morning and although our room wasn't available yet, we were offered another room to freshen up as well as complementary drinks/snacks. The location is superb and you can walk to most of the tourist attractions. It was wonderful to arrive and be able to walk round the corner to the Topaki Palace and quickly start your exploration of Istanbul. One thing though, is that the hotel was building an extension when we were there that would significant increase its capacity. Just hope that with more rooms its high standards will still be the same.

Reviews.Title: “Fantastic hotel, not for everyone”
Reviews.Author: ozzyh
Reviews.Content: As soon as we walked in the people spoke to us by our names, had several people greet us, and then after checking in, our excellent concierge Kemal (who was extremely polished, could be a diplomat) guided us to our room. I have to say I've never experienced such a high level of customer interaction before. Our room was beautiful, we had a wonderful balcony with a view of the blue mosque, and the setting of the hotel in the old prison was marvelous. Since we were on the last day of our romantic getaway, they sent us some special gifts as well, which we really enjoyed thoroughly. Location is obviously spectacular close to everything in sultanahmet. Room service food was good, although not spectacular, and I really enjoyed breakfast. That said, I think the hype around this being one of the best hotels in the world led to too much expectation for me. The last time I spent this kind of money on a hotel was at Sala Samui in Thailand(I know I know comparing hotels in Asia to Europe isn't fair...) and that wowed me. Perhaps my benchmark is off (or I'm not in the right age range, or we needed to stay there longer, or we're too boutique-y....obviously I feel guilty not giving an excellent here) but I just didn't feel the value and almost wished I had stayed again at the Sirkeci Konak where we had stayed earlier in our Turkey trip. Overall wonderful hotel in an amazing setting, but too much hype to live up to. Sorry Four Seasons Istanbul, it's not you, it's me.

Reviews.Title: “I wish I could live here”
Reviews.Author: sjpoyser
Reviews.Content: Simply stunning. Location: the hotel is the perfect base for a first visit to Istanbul when you are looking to 'do' the major tourist sites. It is literally minutes' walk from the Sofya church, the Blue Mosque, the Palace (including the amazing Archaeolgoical Museum). Room: well, I got lucky. Had booked in Deluxe Room (third category up from the entry level) and got a free upgrade to an Executive Suite. Was just perfect, for relaxing, taking afternoon tea, and entertaining. The decor is the usual extremely tasteful (i.e. bland) 4 Seasons style, but with enough Turkish touches not to forget where you were. The room is full of all the usual gadgetry, which is fun, but not at all obtrusive. Staff: unparalleled. From the moment I arrived at the hotel, the staff (and there seemed to be about 3 for every guest) addressed me by name whenever they saw me, and could not have been more helpful, from the concierge to the cleaners. And none of the heavy-handed extortion of tips that mars staying at certain 5* establishments (not to mention any names, the Ritz, Paris...). I would think about staying at the Ciragan during the summer maybe - the 4 Seasons is definitely not a resort hotel - but be warned, the Ciragan is a decent taxi ride away from most of the tourist sites.

Reviews.Title: “A jewl in Istanbul”
Reviews.Author: Payam81
Reviews.Content: I stayed here for 5 days and since I had a very positive experience I thought I share it with the rest of the TA community: Arrival: I arranged to be picked up by the hotelâ€™s BMW 7 Series and while it will cost you probably 4-5 times more than a taxi ride, I feel like it is definitely worth it specially after a 17 hour plane ride in my case. I was greeted by the hotelâ€™s uniformed greeter and he quickly filled me in on some quick facts regarding Istanbul while at the same time asking for the car to be brought up. The ride was about 30 minutes to the airport and although driving in Istanbul is rather more â€œthrillingâ€� than your average US city itâ€™s definitely up to par with places like Rome and most of Eastern Europe so it was nothing new to me specially since I have actually driven in Rome for a few days. I was greeted at the hotel entrance by a multitude of people who all called me by my last name, just like theyâ€™ve known me for years. Check -in, Check-out: Probably one of the quickest I ever experienced. All the paperwork was done in the car during the trip from the airport (another advantage of the hotel transfer) so by the time I was met by the check-in supervisor at the lobby there was little to do except heading to my room while he explained to me a few pointers regarding the hotel and locations of different amenities. I had booked a Four Seasons Executive Suite but they had upgraded me to a One Bedroom Suite which is a bit more roomy and they also really wanted to try and get me in to the Presidential Suite for half the rack rate or about USD 1500/night which I declined cause simply the One Bedroom was overly big enough for me. Check-out took a bit longer cause they were having issues with their system, although the reception staff probably appologized 4 times in 5 minutes despite the fact I assured them it was just fine and I completely understood problems do happen. Location: This place is right in the heart of the old city. Basically expect a lot of commotion during the day with a lot of taxis and tour buses going through the nearby streets, however donâ€™t be afraid of the noise! This hotel is surprisingly quiet and except for the prayer calls from the nearby mosques you can hardly ever hear anything. Special note regarding prayer calls, yes they are LOUD during the day but fortunately our Turkish hosts turn down the volume during the morning call which is around 5:30 AM or so. I never really woke up by the sound in the morning and I could hardly imagine anyone would and if you do, just chalk it up as a part of the whole Turkish experience! Again watch out for cars and buses as you will have to share the streets with them as sidewalks are uneven and narrow not to mention they just simply end at some points in the middle of the road! Food & Drinks: Bottled water is provided everyday (at least in my suite, not sure of the regular rooms). The food at the restaurant was good but not really exceptional. Service at the restaurant was very nice and quick although it seemed like they are â€œactingâ€� at some points and werenâ€™t really fluid but still I say it was good. You could actually forget where you were for a second of two, so I give it zero points on originality which again is expected and not a negative but just to inform you. Room Service food was OK, again nothing superbly tasteful but very well presented nontheless. My biggest issue was with the lounge! Itâ€™s decorated really rather untaistful and to top it I had a martini served to me in a whisky glass cause they didnâ€™t have any martini glasses! No garnish no nothing! I say this was probably the worst martini I ever had so avoid the over priced bar/lounge and head to so many better ones in the town. Cleanliness: This hotel is very well maintained. My suite was spotless! The housekeeping staff meticulously cleaned my messy suite everyday never missing anything. Iâ€™m a germ freak and I can tell you this was by far the cleanest Four Seasons Iâ€™ve ever stayed in! I actually left a very small tip everyday for the housekeeping staff for such a superb job they did everyday. Hotelâ€™s common areas also follow on the same footsteps. There is always one or two people cleaning something somewhere, always moving immediately out of the way before youâ€™ve even approached them in the hallway, then continuing when you move past. Service: Last but not least is of course service. The Turks are generally a very friendly and happy nation and the staff in Four Seasons Sultanahmet are not any different, if not more exceptional! I received probably the most friendly and professional service I have ever received so far at any property be it Four Seasons or not. These guys are really over the top even for a Four Seasons! Aside from pretty much everyone calling you by name, itâ€™s just the general attitude of the staff that makes the difference. Somehow everyone here seems to be genuinely happy to be here and to be of any assistance to you! They make you feel as if they are your family. The concierge team handled every interaction with utmost friendliness and professionalism. I booked two restaurants through them and both turned out to be superb choices. Four Seasons name carries a weight in Istanbul, the two extremely busy restaurants I visited both gave me their best tables despite me booking just few hours earlier and despite being almost a full house! Concierge also gave me good directions to a few shops I needed to check out as well as handled a few itiniary changes again with professionalism and efficiency. Doormen are also particularly friendly here always watching out for you making sure you know where the directions and offering you umbrellas before you even realize itâ€™s raining! Verdict: This hotel delivers top value for the $. I see a lot of complaints about how expensive this hotel is, but I remind you all some things you can never buy. This hotel provides beyond what you can simply buy. Stay here and experience it for yourself but be sure to come back and rate this great hotel and itâ€™s superb staff.

Reviews.Title: “Terrific Location & Service”
Reviews.Author: LaborLawyer
Reviews.Content: Fine establishment, with a well-trained staff, located within walking distance of the main attractions. Remarkable that this was once a prison.

Reviews.Title: “Perefct location, perfect service, perfect ambience!”
Reviews.Author: aLITTLESpoiled
Reviews.Content: Absolutely superb in every way. Service was warm, welcoming, professional, the location could not be better, within a short stroll to Ayaosfia, Blue Mosque and cisterns, and generous sized rooms with every amenity. Walk to Bazaars, too, and shop at SOFA!

Reviews.Title: “Best hotel in Istanbul!”
Reviews.Author: SanThom2000
Reviews.Content: My wife and I went on a romantic weekend to this hotel and had a the best of stays there. We received a compimentary updgrade to a suite and that was huge. The location is perfect if you really want to see all the cultural and historic highlights of Istanbul. The concierge was very helpful when making hotel reservations and they always managed to get us in the most popular restaurants. Great hotel. Highly recommended for a trip to Istanbul!

Reviews.Title: “Four Seasons Hotel, Istanbul, Turkey, Absolutely Magnificent”
Reviews.Author: Litewoman750
Reviews.Content: I must tell you about the most Magnificent trip I have ever taken. My husband and best friends decided to take a get-a-way from the everyday hustle and bustle of our everyday life. We ventured off to Istanbul, Turkey. Our trip started off with a few monkey wrenches as they say as the flight left without us and of course, lost luggage. Once we arrived at the hotel, everything was PERFECT!! From the doorman to the front desk employees, we were greeted like they had known us for many years with a warm, "Welcome Home." The font desk employees asked us about our trip and we advised them of the lost luggage situation. One of them then asked if we had received some information regarding that. I gave him the paperwork and he made a copy. He advised us that they were going to take care of the situation. (the next morning, we were told that the suitcase had been located and we would have it by the afternoon ) They then asked what size of clothes both of us wear and they came out with 2- beatiful bags filled with all the toiletries imaginable to carry us through the night. It even included underclothes that were very confortable and socks to keep our feet warm. That was definetly what I believe to be "over and above" They make you feel like you are the only guests in their hotel. They would greet us by our names and were always showing that personal attention. There was also another incident that I must tell you. One night we went to a restaurant across the street and there was a little shop nearby and the gentleman in the store had a coin collection from coins all over the world. I looked through and noticed he did not have a lot of the new American coins. (the ones with the states) We finished there, went back to the room and I decided to take him some coins I had. Everyone from my party was tired so I decided to go by myself. It was late and when I walked out, the doorman noticed I was alone. He followed me to the store, waited and escorted me back to the hotel. He went that "extra mile" If you want luxury and personal attention and are going to Istanbul, the Four Seasons is definitetly the place to stay.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful hotel, fantastic location”
Reviews.Author: luxurybackpacker
Reviews.Content: Our recent short break to Istanbul was fabulous in every way. The Four Seasons is bang in the heart of the main architectural sites and is a real oasis amidst the hectic city. The room was excellent and the service fantastic. The Sunday brunch buffet is the meal worth staying in the hotel for. Use the ferries to get across to the modern side of town where the best restaurants are and make time for the Bosphorus scenic cruise - the waterways are a great place to be in the heat - 36C there last week so would not want to travel here in July or August. The only thing missing at the Four Seasons is a pool, and we could have used a couple of hours on a lounger and a dip at the end of each day. When you see the pool at the Ciragan Palace from the water, it is tempting!! The Four Seasons is perfect for a first visit to Istanbul however and I would wholeheartedly recommend it.

Reviews.Title: “best hotel in its location”
Reviews.Author: docwatson_236
Reviews.Content: If you want to stay in Sultanahmet, which is the best location for first-time visitors to Istanbul interested in tourist sites, the Four Seasons is the only real luxury choice in the neighborhood. Despite being in a busy and noisy part of town, the hotel manages to convey the serenity of a private garden, even if its history as a former prison may give some guests a few chilling fanasies. The service is impeccable, the rooms are well-appointed, and the garden dining area is lovely. However, it IS expensive for Turkey, and the meals are overpriced when you can simply go around the corner and order a meal for a third of the cost. Although its restaurant is said to be one of the best in the neighborhood, I found the food to be only moderately good -- certainly not on a level of a great New York restaurant. This is not the place for a budget traveler. And I suspect that after one has been to Istanbul a few times, the crazy activity of the Sultanahmet neighborhood with all its tour buses and aggressive carpet salesmen may get old. There are other comfortable and acceptable hotels in the area (say, the Blue House Hotel) which offer the same great location near the Blue Mosque, at a much cheaper cost. Not as luxurious, but a decent alternative.

Reviews.Title: “a wonderful refuge”
Reviews.Author: Gree
Reviews.Content: We fled across the road to the Four Seasons when our long-booked hotel turned out to be a ghastly disappontment. We were welcomed with warmth and courtesy, and loved every aspect of our stay. Perhaps the ravishing flowers deserve a special mention - but we loved the staff, the public areas, and the stylish decor. All in all we were reminded that paying twice as much for a five-times-better product is money very well spent!

Reviews.Title: “Four Seaons always manages to surprise”
Reviews.Author: toujours28
Reviews.Content: When we made the reservation for an executive suite earlier this month, we put in a request for a view, if possible. What we weren't expecting was what we got: a room with 3 different views. Located on the top floor, room 323 is a spacious executive suite, with a separate living room, bedroom, and a very large bathroom. Two windows faced Aya Sofia, reminding you that Istanbul was right outside waiting for you. From another part of the living room we could see the hotel courtyard and garden, a relaxing view if a little unnatural in its extreme neatness. The bedroom and the bathroom looked out onto the Bosphorous, and I can't imagine why anyone would have watched TV in the bathroom when you could take a bath while looking out onto the sea. The service was faultless. Knowing the brand, you come to a Four Seasons hotel expecting a certain kind of service, and still they manage to surprise you: book markers that suddently appear on top of books you leave lying around, a surprise birthday cake delivered to the room on the special day, a huge DVD library to choose from, an ice bucket that is never empty... the hotel is really a haven of peace in a beautiful but chaotic city. If I had to fault anything, it would be the restaurant. We had dinner there one evening, when we were too tired to go out, and everything was correct but never special. The dishes on the menu were perhaps a bit too creative for the cooking behind them, so the menu might have benefitted from some simpler but well-executed alternatives. But then again, if you think about it as a hotel restaurant, it is fine. Breakfast fared better than dinner, but compared to the breakfasts at other Four Seasons hotels I've stayed in, I'd rate it a little bit lower. It was good and not as expensive as other hotel breakfasts out there ($29), but not spectacular. For anyone having trouble deciding between the Four Seasons and the Ciragan Palace, as we did, here's my take on the two places: choose the Four Seasons if you want to get to know the city of Istanbul, and the Ciragan if you want a relaxing vacation on the Bosphorous and aren't expecting to go out much. The Ciragan has a pool and an enviable view, but is it desperately in the middle of nowhere and not well communicated with the rest of the city, as access is through a small coastal road (think lots of noise, think lots of traffic, and you'll be thinking in the right direction). The same will apply to the new resort that Four Seasons is opening on the Bosphorous in a few months, since it is located right next to the Ciragan Kempinski. The current Four Seasons, on the other hand, is in a beautiful part of Sultanahment and well positioned for exploring the city. Even in June it was very hot in Istanbul, however, so we did miss having a pool in the hotel. Just something to keep in mind. As a side note, when we made the reservation the hotel recommended booking transportation from the airport with them. We chose not to book their $110 limo service and took a cab instead ($20-25). For such a short cab ride, I think we made the right choice!

Reviews.Title: “Luxurious yet detached”
Reviews.Author: phatsinoz
Reviews.Content: Having had the fortune of staying at many Four Seasons Hotels, I pretty much knew what to expect. Despite the impeccable service, world-class furnishings and superb location, I couldn't help but feel that you are detached from Istanbul as a city within the secluded walls of the Hotel. Yes, the views from your hotel room are amazing and from the moment you leave the front doors, you are thrust into the historical mecca that is Istanbul. Yet although I can't find much to criticise about the hotel, I did not feel that my stay was representative of being in Istanbul. The seclusion and over-indulgent service (sometimes rather too rehearsed and stoical) meant that I could have stayed in the Hotel the entire weekend without having experienced any of the "real" Istanbul that was on offer.

Reviews.Title: “Simply the best!”
Reviews.Author: EMTBStation53
Reviews.Content: I have had the good fortune to travel for the past 50 years and have stayed in a number of 5 star hotels throughout the world. The Four Seasons Istanbul is possibly the finest hotel in the world! We checked in with three other couples. When the receptionist checked us in, she let us know in a most discrete manner that we had been upgraded to a corner suite (Room 214). The room was superb - extremely large, high ceilings and perfectly appointed. There were four enormous windows in the room with a view of Aga Sophia (which was even better if you went out on the window ledge!). The bathroom had both a tub and stall shower with a separate toilet room with window. The bathroom amenities were very high quality and abundant. There was also a small screen TV in the bathroom. (That TV complemented the 42" plasma TV in the bedroom/sitting room area). We had a separate entrance foyer with bar area and two enormous closets. We had let the hotel know that we were on our honeymoon, and when we returned to our suite the first evening, they had strewn rose petals all over the bed and bathtub, had a chilled bottle of champagne waiting for us, heart shaped candles waiting to be lit, and a tray of strawberries and apricots with various dipping sauces. That was simply over the top! What we liked most about the hotel were the quality of the service, the setting of the hotel, the calm ambience within its walls and the beauty of the flowers and interior courtyard. It was truly an oasis in the midst of the hustle of Istanbul. We were treated superbly by every single staff member. The concierge recommended perfect restaurants close by. We did not eat at the hotel since we prefer to sample local cuisine. We found the perfect pastry shop called Cigdem on the street with the trolley tracks just about across from McDonalds. On the Monday morning we were there, all of the locals were lined up to buy pastries which simply reinforced the fact that we had chosen the right place. We loved the Turks, Istanbul and the Four Seasons and would return in a heartbeat. The hotel is expensive ($650 a night), but I felt it was worth every cent we paid. I've paid higher prices in other 5 star hotels and never felt that I got what I paid for. The Four Seasons Istanbul is simply the best!

Reviews.Title: “BEAUTIFUL SUMPTUOUS HOTEL, IMPECABLE SERVICE”
Reviews.Author: sheilajgw
Reviews.Content: Absolutely beautiful, luxurious sourroundings, perfect service, center of old city shopping --nothing negative to say in any way --Other glowing reviews are accurate--would recommend to anyone wanting luxury hotel in Istanbul.

Reviews.Title: “It's the location, stupid! Well okay, service is perfect too”
Reviews.Author: ScottN
Reviews.Content: The price of staying here is definitely high, but the location is absolutely perfect. It is the only luxury hotel near the major sites (Blue Mosque, Grand Bazaar, Topkapi Palace, Aya Sofia). Add to that being in a historical building (former political prison), perfect discreet service, immaculately clean rooms with the best of everything, and you have what must be one of the very best hotels in the world. Even at $700-$800 /night, I felt it was well worth the money to stay in and near the very best of Istanbul. As a former political prison, the walls and rooms of the common areas are definitely solid and rather heavy. The photos on the Four Seasons web site makes it look "lighter" when in actuality everything is quite "heavy" looking. The mixture of Oriental and European influences is accurate however, giving an exotic air. We tried for a standard or superior room, but there were none available. I checked at the hotel and it appears there are only four (4) standard rooms, so definitely book early if you want those. I ended up reserving a Deluxe room for four nights upon entry to Istanbul (the majority of the rooms are "Deluxe"), and then a Four Seasons Room for a two nights before leaving Turkey. Both rooms were equally great, but the Four Seasons Room was HUGE. Based on its location surrounded by other buildings, the best views are of the inner courtyard garden and restaurant, NOT of the outside. The beds, well, I never knew beds could be that comfortable or linens that crisp. Bathrooms are expansive light marble with a touch of "byzantine" mosaic blue-green glass tiles. There is a separate shower and tub, and separate toilet room. All bathrooms will have hand-made kilim area rugs. The 44" flat panel televisions are almost too large for the regular rooms. There is a small wall tv in the bathroom. Bottled mineral water is provided gratis. For the Four Seasons Room, add a large sitting area and gee-whiz gadgetry like electronic shades. I've read complaints about the proximity to the Blue Mosque and the first call to prayer in the AM. We could hardly hear it from our room, certainly not enough to wake us from slumber. The windows have triple panes. Perhaps the rooms in the front of the hotel facing forward may have more of an issue, but this is a guess. At $35 each, the American Breakfast is a bit steep, but is great comfort food (eggs, coffee, fresh oj, potatoes, muffins and danish, fruit, pork BACON) instead of the standard Turkish breakfast (cheese, raw cucumbers, tomatoes, olives, hard boiled eggs, bologna, toast). There are also less expensive ala carte selections. Dinner was good but not worth the price, eat out instead. The Four Seasons has purchased adjacent properties and are currently expanding the hotel, so WARNING: If you face the back of the hotel, you will probably hear construction noise, sometimes as late as 8PM or 9PM, including weekends. The hotel concierge booked us a private guide over two days. Compared to other guides we had in Turkey, we were disappointed to get a "by the book" guide that had nothing extra to say. Generally, we were not satisfied with the recommendations for shops or restaurants by the concierge, although their actual service was prompt and professional. The Four Seasons is building a "sister" property directly on the Bosphorus, you may want to check to see if it is open when you go. For tourists, I still think this hotel has the better location.

Reviews.Title: “A Hotel Fit for a Sultan!”
Reviews.Author: kingsroadgal
Reviews.Content: We were really wowed by this hotel. I had a bit of a rough start with the hotel, because they asked me several times to reconfirm our reservation for some reason, and would not give us any guarantee of connecting rooms, or even rooms close to each other - we had booked two rooms for five nights. We needn't have worried. We were assigned rooms at the end of the hall facing each other. They upgraded one of our rooms to a suite, although frankly, our other room, a Four Seasons room, was absolutely fabulous on its own, and could have easily accomodated the four of us, if a little snugly. I actually thought it was a suite, as it had a very substantial sitting area with couch and chairs. The Executive Suite was also beautiful with separate living room and bedroom, long hallway, and large bathroom with upgraded toiletries (Bulgari - regular rooms have l'Occitane) The good points of the hotel are many. Location is absolutely the top one to have in Istanbul. You can really walk to most major tourist attractions. And I agree with a previous review that there is little reason to cross the Golden Horn. Everything you need is in Sultanahmet, unless you are really staying for an extended period. Food at the hotel is great. Room service breakfast includes a toaster which is brought to your room so you can have hot toast. I also loved their waffles. Lattes were served absolutely hot. Dinner at the hotel was also some of the best food we had in Istanbul (especially the "smashed salad", which was something like gazpacho). Great and varied bread was served. On our second visit to the restaurant, we were surprised to see no baklava on the menu after we had had it the night before. We ordered another dessert. The waiter, however, noting our preference, made the effort to find some baklava, and served it to us as a complimentary after dessert treat. There were also some petit fours served with coffee after dinner. The service was attentive. The hotel has a very nice gym which is well equipped and convenient, although it closed at 10 p.m. The gym at the Tokyo Four Seasons is open 24 hours. One fun amenity is the delivery each afternoon or evening of a delicious treat to the room. For my children, this treat was kid-friendly, such as cookies with chocolate sauce for dipping. For us, the treats consisted of petit fours, cookies, and the like. It was a nice extra. There was always plenty of bottled water provided in the room since the tap water in Istanbul is to be avoided. We did, however, brush our teeth with the tap water a couple of times without any ill effect. I can hardly think of anything bad to say about this hotel. It is super pricey, but I think we felt that we really received value for money. The only thing that even crossed my mind as being a negative was that the water pressure in the shower seemed a little low to me, although they did have those large 12" shower heads. Oh, and for light sleepers, the first call to prayer from the Blue Mosque is audible in some of the rooms at 5:30 a.m. We managed to sleep through it most of the time, but light sleepers might want to take note. Did I mention the beautiful gardens surrounding the restaurant? I could go on forever about all the great features of this hotel. I would absolutely return to this fabulous place. Definitely worth a splurge.

Reviews.Title: “I hope when I die I find out that the FS Istanbul is heaven...”
Reviews.Author: zwool
Reviews.Content: Istanbul is an amazingly special place. The blend of east and west is beyond compare, and I can't imagine my stay being nearly what it was if I had stayed elsewhere in Istanbul. I arrived on a 10 hour non-stop flight from New York, so I booked the hotel car. I was a little weary because it cost $135, but figured it'd be better than hassling with a taxi driver who may not speak that much English. As soon as I stepped through customs, a man in a four seasons suit with a sign greeted me. While I stepped away to the Citibank ATM in the lobby of the airport, he made a quick phone call. By the time I had made it back from the ATM, the hotel's BMW 7 series had come from around the corner and my bags were packed. The man who met me wasn't the driver, and he disappeared back into the airport - without the slightest hesitation in a way that would make it seem like he wanted a tip. On the way in the car, the driver had me fill out the normal info you'd do upon check-in. He also pointed out some of the main sights. Upon arriving at the hotel, I was greeted by name. The concierge informed me that the final inspection of my room was taking place (I arrived early in the morning way before check-in). He offered me some complimentary tea in the beautiful lobby. 5 minutes later my key was brought to me. By the time I arrived in my room, my luggage had arrived. Again, not one employee in any way signaled for a tip. The room itself is the Four Seasons as its finest. There was a Bose CD player, a dvd player, and 46" plasma tv in the room (i booked the standard room). The bathroom was one of the largest standard room FS bathrooms I've seen, with a separate shower, toilet, and bathtub. There's also a TV in the bathroom. I have to admit - the concept of a hotel in a former prison made me think that the FS would have to sacrifice some on amenities. But somehow they made it work. The decor is the regular four seasons classic, with a great Turkish flair. I really believe that the concierges at fine hotels can make or break your stay. They lead you to the sights and the best restaurants, and give you the best advice. Here, the concierges didn't fail. Burak (one of the concierges) was one of the best I've come across. His recommendations for restaurants hit the spot perfectly - for both seafood and traditional turkish. The rest of the staff, too, was amazing. Everyone remembered my name. They remembered only after one day in the restaurant that I'm allergic to milk and so brought soy milk with my coffee. They remembered that I don't like the chocolate cookies that they serve with the tea (so i'd get two sugar cookies instead). The doormen remembered where the taxi took me in the morning, and would ask me how it was. Finally - the location. You can't beat it. The hotel is literally wedged between the 3 main sights - the Hagia Sofia, the Blue Mosque, and the Topkapi Palace. The Grand Bazaar is only a 10 minute walk away. I only crossed to the part of town called Beyoglu once (which is where most of the other grand hotels are). If you're going to splurge once in life, spend at least a night here. And a little hint - if you do stay, some taxi drivers don't speak very good english or know where the hotel is, so tell them you're going to the Hagia Sofia and then you just walk the last 50 meters from there.

Reviews.Title: “Best hotel in the World”
Reviews.Author: travelerLasVegas
Reviews.Content: We knew there are many luxury hotels in Istanbul like Ciragan palce, swiss hotel or the Hyatt and the Ritz but we choose this one, some of our friends told us about it and they were right, we are from Las Vegas and we have seen many nice ones but with everything combine this was truly the best, we love it so much l wanted to write a rewiew which l never do, so there, expensive but worth every dollar.how ever we will try the Ciragan Palace next time we had a dinner there it looks fantastick.

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful & Fabulous”
Reviews.Author: cxgarcia
Reviews.Content: From the moment we were greeted at the airport by a Four Seasons staff member, we knew we were in for an amazing experience. Our greeter walked us to our car where our driver was very pleasant. Upon arrival at this beautiful hotel, every single staff person treated us like family and made us feel welcome. Every request was granted immediately. The room was perfect, the restaurant was great, the roof top bar had amazing views of the water and the old part of Istanbul. The concierge was excellent! During our departure, the excellent service continued. Our same greeter met us at the airport and even checked us in at the airline counter! Yes, the Four Seasons is pricey but you get what you pay for and more! This particular property is consistently rated highly by Travel & Leisure...and now I know why.

Reviews.Title: “Perfection in Wonderful Istanbul!”
Reviews.Author: Trip Advisor from Dallas, TX
Reviews.Content: We stayed 3 nights in June, 2006. What a wonderful location, staff, food, service. The location is fabulous for touring Istanbul. You can walk to most major attractions from the hotel. Our room was facing the interior courtyard garden which is beautifully landscaped. The bathroom was very large & lovely. We loved everything about this hotel and we felt very safe here. We did not spend much time at the hotel because there is so much to see in Istanbul. All of the hotel's restaurant recommendations were great. However, we went to a Turkish Bath that the hotel recommended which I would not recommend if there are women in your party. If you ask the hotel for a recommendation on Turkish Baths, be sure to ask for a bath that is respectful to the women, not just the men. We did not use the hotel to find a guide. Instead, we used Credo Tours & were very satisfied with their service. If you are spendiing a few days in Istanbul, I would definitely recommend this hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Great service- luxury hotel”
Reviews.Author: membertrip
Reviews.Content: All previous reviews are true! The service is incredible. The staff does everything to make you feel comfortable. What I liked most were the 2 rooftop terrasses with a few sun loungers and Bosporus view. Normally,t here is no service on the terrasses, but one evening,they had a sunset bar with drinks an snacks. We booked a deluxe room and I asked for a room on the 4th floor with a balcony. When I saw the room, I was a bit disappointed, because I expected a bigger room (according to the pictures). Probably, the 4th floor rooms are smaller because of the roof. The bathroom was big and luxurious. Next time, I would book a room on the 3d floor. Don't go for a room on the ground floor (no view). The spa is small but nice designed (also the dressing room). I had 2 massages which turned out great. Is there a downside? The prices!!! For the massage 60 min. I payed nearly 200 CHF, for 2 salades, 2 mineral waters at lunch 60 CHF. As a result,we never had dinner at the hotel. They were some very nice, fancy, modern restaurants with large terrasses and Bosporus view (Vogue, 360,Leb-i Derya).

Reviews.Title: “What a hotel!”
Reviews.Author: DaneP
Reviews.Content: Two friends and I stayed for 6 nights at the Four Seasons in Istanbul, and we each felt that it was one of the highlights of our trip to Turkey. The service is cheerful, prompt, and impeccable, from the gracious and helpful curbside service during which you are greeted by name to the nightly turndown service and fresh fruit plates in the rooms. Bookmarks are left in any books you've left sitting out. The bed sheets are folded in such a way that there's a pocket of extra room at the bottom for tall people. And whenever you leave the hotel, the doormen provide the taxi drivers (who, in Istanbul, seemed to know surprisingly little about how to get to various restaurants and cultural attractions) detailed driving directions. There's no real spa, just two massage rooms, but the massages we received here were far better than the ineffectual oil rubs the Ritz Carlton claims are massages at their larger (and tacky) spa. The location of the hotel is unbeatable, with its terraces hovering between the Aya Sofya and the Blue Mosque. A truly wonderful hotel, among the very best I've ever experienced.
